stem: A 250-lb client (BMI 42) with a history of Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA) is recovering from spinal surgery with a PCA pump. Based on the documentation in the Capnography & Sleep Surveillance Log, what is the most appropriate nursing action?

options.text: Apply the client's CPAP machine and reposition to a lateral or semi-Fowler position.
Increase the basal rate on the PCA to manage the client's pain.
Call a Code Blue for complete respiratory arrest.

rationale.correct: The client is experiencing Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA) exacerbated by opioid use. The sawtooth waveform and pauses in breathing with loud snoring indicate a physical obstruction (the tongue/soft tissue falling back) rather than a loss of central respiratory drive. The immediate priority is to open the airway using CPAP and proper positioning. Naloxone is not the first choice because the client's respiratory rate is 12, indicating respiratory drive is present, but the airway is blocked.
clinicalPearls: Opioids relax the airway muscles, worsening OSA.
Capnography (EtCO2) is more sensitive than SpO2 for detecting airway obstruction because it shows the moment the airway stops, whereas SpO2 lags by minutes.
In obese patients, supine positioning can be detrimental after opioid administration.

questionTrap.trap: Choosing naloxone just because opioids are mentioned.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Assess the snoring and BMI. If the patient is working hard to breathe but failing because of a block, it's an airway problem (OSA). If the patient isn't trying to breathe at all, it's a respiratory drive problem.

mnemonic.title: OSA vs RDA
mnemonic.expansion: OSA: Snoring and Sawtooth (Blockage). RDA: Shallow and Slow (Narcosis).

exhibits.title: Waveform Analysis
exhibits.content: The capnography waveform shows a sawtooth pattern with frequent flat-lines (apnea) lasting 15-20 seconds followed by rapid, high CO2 spikes (60+). EtCO2 is rising from a baseline of 35 to 54.

exhibits.title: Vital Signs & SpO2
exhibits.content: SpO2: 84% (Drops only during the flat-lines of capnogram). Respiratory Rate: 12 (Stable-looking, but with pauses). Condition: Client is snoring loudly and has recessions in the neck during breathing attempts.

exhibits.title: PCA Protocol
exhibits.content: 1. Morphine 1mg demand. 2. Basal rate: 0.5 mg/hr. 3. Continuous pulse oximetry and capnography mandated for BMI > 40.
